JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 17.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 17, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

THE ALUMNI BANQUET

MUSICAL CLUBS WIN GLORY

HOPKINS AT THE INAUGURATION

CHAMPION S. A. MILE RELAYERS

To Be Held at the Hotel Belvedere on
February 22 — Year's Officers
to Be Announced.

Large and Interested Audience Turns
Out to Hear the Annual Concert in McCoy Hall.

A Committee Appointed to Arrange the
Details—Position in Parade Dependent on Numbers.

Games at the Armory a Great Success
Hopkins Lowers Record—Eller
Stars for Georgetown.

At the Alumni Banquet, which is
to be held at Hotel Belvedere on
the evening of February 22, the results of the balloting for the coming year's officers of the Alumni
Association of the Johns Hopkins
University will be announced. The
ticket is:

The Musical Clubs gave their annual concert and dance in McCoy
Hall last Tuesday evening. The
weather did not hinder a large and
enthusiastic audience from attending and showing their approval by
calling for repeated encores. Nearly all the seats were taken, and
the clubs feel that they have been
rewarded to some extent for their
labors by the good results from last
Tuesday's concert.
The concert itself was probably
the best the clubs have given in
late years. Favorable comment has
been heard on all sides, and very
little complaint. The Instrumental
Club made an especially good showing, and the instrumental solos held
the attention of everyone. The
quartette and "Mrs. Winslow" won
the laurels for the vocal side of
the concert. The leaders and members of the clubs .are to be congratulated on their good work.
Those who took part in the concert
were: Messrs. Gillet, Fulton, Getz,
Lloyd, Ray, Bacchus, Paulus,
Schmied, Bowden, White, Eiseman,
Spencer, Aler, Scovell, Donoho,
Marston, Howell, Supplee, Spieker,
Randall, Wagner, Breuninger, JacObs, Niles, Weber, Melamet, Niles,
Schneeberger, Uhler, Coblentz,
Lynch, Uhler, Knipp, Tappan, Geissel, Steinmuller, Gminder, Lauchheimer, Cole, Baker, Marshall and
Linthicum.
The ushers were Messrs. Huck,
Dorsey, Rice, Branham, Richardson and Brinton.
The concert was followed by the
usual dance. Last Tuesday's affair
proved to be an especially enjoyable
one. A good orchestra's services
had been secured, and it furnished
excellent music for the new tango
dance. Everyone seemed to enjoy
the dancing thoroughly, and regrets were heard on all sides when
midnight put an end to the pleasure.
Enthusiasts were heard to say that,
for a long time McCoy Hall had
never been the scene of a dance
where the attendance was as large,
the dancers as enthusiastic, the women as beautifully gowned and the
music as good as last Tuesday.
• On Saturday, February 22, the
clubs will give a concert and dance
in Salisbury. On the twenty-fifth
they will perform at one of the Baltimore churches, and will go to
Catonsville on the twenty-seventh.
Two or three other concerts are being planned to follow these, but no
dates have as yet been definitely
arranged.

With the assurance of a representative portion of the student
body at a mass-meeting last week
that Johns Hopkins would have a
large number of marchers in the inaugural parade in Washington on
March 4, Chairman Freddie Lee
appointed the following committee
to arrange details for the University's delegation: Walter D. Sutton
(chairman), John Sharp Dickinson, C. Leland Getz, President J.
Miller Leake of the Hopkins Wilson Club, John C. Branham, Steuart D. White, Blanchard Randall,
Arthur Primrose and Lewis Breuninger. Freddie Lee will also serve.
The committee, while composed
of undergraduates with but two exceptions, will make an effort to enlist alumni, medical, graduate and
undergraduate students.
In view of the fact that a suspension of exercises has been
granted by the faculty and the
proximity of Washington, the University should turn out the second
largest delegation in the college
men's division of the parade.
Princeton, of course, will lead in
numbers. Already over 1,200 have
decided to march for their former
president, and they will be first
in line.
Johns Hopkins; University of
Virginia and Davidson College will
follow Princeton according to the
size of the delegation.
A letter received from the committee of arrangements for the
parade said in part:
"Therefore, it is apparent that
the position of your delegation will
depend on the result of your efforts
to enlist men."
The question of what is to be
worn by the marchers has not yet
been decided upon, but it is hoped
that caps and gowns will be selected. Across the gowns a band bearing "Johns Hopkins" will be worn.
All marchers must be dressed in
a uniform style. If it is decided not
to wear caps and gowns, some other
style of dress will be selected.
Hopkins wants second place in
the line, and it will not be to the
credit of the students to fall 'behind any other institution than
Princeton. The demonstration is
non-partisan, without political significance, and will be purely patriotic in chatacter. The faculty has
allowed a holiday, and it is with the
condition that the student body
should go to a man. It may seldom
occur that the University will have a

Johns Hopkins, in the most thrilling of the relay races at the Fifth
Regiment - Johns Hopkins games
last Saturday night at the Armory,
lowered the only South Atlantic
Association record broken during
the meet.
The event, too, makes the Black
4nd Blue team the champion South
Atlantic mile relayers. The time
was 3 minutes 3375 seconds as
against 3 minutes and 37 seconds
registered by the McCulloh Athletic
Club some time ago.
Captain Catlin, Lloyd, Wells and
McDonagh of the Hopkins team
had saved up their strength at the
sacrifice of other events and throwing all energy into the race they
were. determined to nose the victory
from Washington and Lee and the
University of Virginia.
Perhaps the prettiest run of the
four was made by Lloyd, the third
man, who made up a dangerous
lead, giving Catlin one yard to his
advantage at the start of the last
lap. Catlin was pushed for the position, but broke the tape only a few
inches ahead of Cooke, Virginia's
star relay man.
The race was the most interesting and thrilling of the meet, and
a suprisingly large gallery of Hopkins rooters made a convention-like
din of cheers and hullabaloos when
Catlin was carried from the finish
by Hopkins men.
Another relay won by Hopkins—
that for the State mile championship
—called forth cheering. St. John's
College withdrew from the event,
leaving Western Maryland to contest Hopkins. Wagner, Ray, Stiehel and Groover composed the team.
Bob Eller of Georgetown was the
shining star of the games. He
carried off four firsts, three of
which were South Atlantic championships. The other championship
was won by Gallagher, also of
Georgrtown. The events were the
S. A. A. A. U. 100-yard dash,
ioo-yard hurdles, 220-yard dash
and the open 100-yard hurdles, all
won by Eller; and the 88o-yard run
won by Gallagher.
In the 100-yard dash for the
South Atlantic championship Wagner of Hopkins was second to Eller,
but the men were so close that to
those who stood near the finish it
looked as if the Hopkins man had
won. White and Voshell placed in the heats.
In the field events other Hopkins
men took places. Blanco, the Porto

Together with this ballot there
was sent out to all graduates of the
University a ballot for members of
the Alumni Council. The Alumni
Council is the alumni body which
confers with the University authorities on matters of common interest.
They are, also, the organizers of
movements in which it is desirable
that all the alumni should take part.
Those chosen for the honor serve
four years, but all members do not
vacate office the same year. At
least one of the successful candidates must be a new member of the
Council.

THE MADISON

Y. W. C. A. Conference.

A conference for volunteer and
employed workers of the Young
Women's Christian Association was
opened in McCoy Hall last Monday, February io, at 8.15 P. M.
The meeting was presided over by
Joshua Levering and was addressed
by Dr. Walter Rauschenbusch of
the Rochester Theological Seminary on the subject of "Christian
Social Service." Dr. Rauschenbusch is an authority on this subject, having written numerous books
and delivered a series of lectures
before the leading universities of
this country. He was one of the
leaders in the recent convention of
the Federal Council of Churches of
Christ in America, and has done
much work in mapping out the
program of community service,
which many churches have adopted.
Besides this meeting, there were
two other sessions of the conference, both of which were held in
the Y. W. C. A. Building, Park
avenue and Monument street. On
Tuesday there was a session from
II to 1.30, which was continued
at 3.45 P. M. The last session was
held on Wednesday, at 10.30 A. M.
and 8.15 P. M. The meetings were
addressed by Baltimore pastors, and
by the chairmen of different councils and committees.

Carl Bernhardt, 'o8, formerly
editor-in -chief of THE NEwsLETTER, has given up newspaper
work and has gone into the automobile business.
In honor of the late Rev. Arthur
H. Ewing, Ph. D. 'cm, the last
president, the name of the Christian
College of Allahabad, India, is to
be changed to the Arthur Ewing
College.
The Georgia Alumni Association
will hold its annual banquet on February 22 or March i at Atlanta.
Dr. Thomas R. Boggs, associate
professor of medicine, will represent the University.
J. I. Butler, M. D. '91, late of
New Haven, Conn, has removed to
Tucson, Ariz., where he is resident surgeon to the Rodgers Hospital. D. Butler is remembered by
many Hopkins men for his fine
work on the football team.
The Baltimore Alumni will have
a smoker and field night at the
Hopkins Club on February 21. On
Saturday, the twenty-second, the
annual banquet will take place at
the Hotel Belvedere. The list of
speakers has not been announced.

Alumni Magazine Out.

The second number of the Johns'
Hopkins Alumni Magazine appeared
during the past week. Besides
alumni notes and a general review
of events around the University
during the past two months, the
number contains five special articles.
Dr. Raney gives a detailed description of the plans of Gilman Hall,
Dr. Hurd writes on "Early Days of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital and
Medical School," Dr. Howland describes "The Harriet Lane Home
for Invalid Children," Professor
Buchner outlines the work of the
"Summer School" and ProfessOr
Brush writes an article on the
"Johns Hopkins Club."

every contract that is returned to
him signed, there should also be
turned in a copy of the ad to be
inserted.

From Far-Away India.

An interesting communication recently received by THE NEWSLETTER is a report of the A. E. L.
Mission College, Guntur, India,
which was sent by L. L. Uhl, Ph.
D., president of the college, who has
spent his life spreading Western
learning in this far-off quarter of
the globe. From the report one
gets a picture of a college so
strangely unlike any college with
which we are familiar, that it
seems to be from another world
or another age.
In the first place, the enrollment
is made up of 712 Hindus, 195
Christians and 61 Mohammedans,
together with a smaller number of
Visva Brahmans, Vaisyas, Naidis,
Reddis, Salis, Bhogams, and so on.
At the April examinations only
72Y2 per cent, of the pupils passed
the examinations and were promoted, which shows the extreme difficulty which missionaries have to
enable Hindus to master Western
culture. Irregular attendance is
complained of not only in regard to
the pupils but also in regard to the
masters, who often stay away on
account of Hindu ceremonies, indisposition and frequent summonses
for jury duty. At the meetings of
the literary society, we are told, the
students fill even the doors and
aisles to hear the debates, showing
the eagerness of the students to
learn.

government was being run to the

a kicker, but that a small leaven of
that disagreeable species was absolutely necessary to make the world
go 'round. THE NEWS-LETTER

belief that a cheerful knocker is an
indispensable member of society

Prof. Buchanan Lectures.

Prof. Milton A. Buchanan of the
University of Toronto delivered a
series of three lectures last week in
the Romance Seminary on the famous Spanish satirist and journalist,
Mariano Jose de Larra. On Wednesday the visitor's subject was
"The Life and Writings of Larra";
on Thursday he spoke on "Larra's
Views on Contemporary Romanticism," and on Friday he discussed
"Larra's Attitude Toward Political
and Social Conditions." Professor
Buchanan is one of a number of
men who will be brought here this
year to deliver lectures before the
Romance department.

Professor Ames' Lectures.

Prof. Ames' course of lectures, at
Northwestern University, will begin on Monday evening, February
24. The course is called "The Norman W. Harris Lectures" and is
given annually upon the same general plan as our Turnbull lectures.
The subject of the course is "The
Constitution of Matter," and six
lectures will be delivered, one each
day of the week of February 24.
On his way out to Evanston, Dr.
Ames will meet the John Hopkins
Alumni at a dinner in Cleveland.
After the course at Northwestern
University is completed he will go
to Chicago, where a luncheon will
be held in his honor by the Northwestern Alumni Association of the
Johns Hopkins University. On
March 4 Dr. Ames will deliver two
lectures at Madison, Wis.—one to
the University of Wisconsin and
one to the members Of the faculty
in physics.

Item in the Public Press:

"HOPKINS TO MARCH IN PARADE
Students in Cap and Gown to Join
Inaugural Procession."

Of course there's no need for
more publicity at Hopkins. Why
spend good money when we are
getting free space such as this?
Just think how much it adds to the
dignity of the University. Our
numbers will be doubled next year.
Would the Third Ward Democrats
and Concord Clubbers send their
sons anywhere else after hobnobbing with our learned professors as
they two-step down Pennsylvania
avenue? Of course not:'twould be
absurd to think of anything else.

MORE PUBLICITY.
"President Wilson Invited to Referee
Armory Meet."

Of course he will come—it will
add so much to his dignity.

Lacrosse prospects are brightening with each practice. Last Saturday the attack showed evidences of
real team work, driving in goal
after goal, and the coaches were
very well pleased. At the next
regular practice the defense began
to show signs of the drilling of the
past two months. This is particularly evident in one or two cases.
Price, for one, is showing marked
improvement and, if he continues the
good work, it looks as though he
may hold down a place on the team.
Beatty, too, is looming up as a
possibility; his stick-work can still
be improved, but it is getting more
certain with each practice and he
is working hard for a position.
The trouble, at present, is that
a number of men are shirking. La
Motte, for example, has not yet
been out, and several others are
cutting practice entirely too often.
Besides hurting the team, these men
are seriously risking their own
chances, for the squad is large;
several good men are trying for
each position, and it is the men
who are out at every practice who
will land the jobs.

February 13, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

I have come to the conclusion that
cartoonists are all wrong in making
woman suffragists hideous beings.
At least, the one with whom I sat
out a dance last Tuesday evening
certainly had beautiful eyes, to my
way of thinking at any rate. "Oh,
there goes Grace," she began, as we
took our seats out in the hall: "I
haven't seen her since Mrs. Pratt
gave that tea to the new members
of the Equal Suffrage League. I
suppose you have signed the petition."
The cynical smile which came
over my face as I said, "What petition?" suffered an untimely eclipse
when my eyes met the two blue eyes
of my companion, which now had
a strangely unfamiliar look. But
_perhaps it was only the shadow of
some dancer that fell upon us for
a moment that made me fear that
the eyes of my companion were indeed like summer skies (to which
I had secretly compared them),
which so easily become overcast
with clouds, the prophets of a *coming storm.
"No, as I have never had the
pleasure of meeting any real suffragettes, I have never signed the petition. Are they really so very ugly ?"
I said in vain hope of changing the
topic of the conversation.
"Oh," she said, "I have a book
here which you can sign without
having to meet the awful suffragettes," and she pulled out from
nowhere a beautiful, gilt edge memorandum book. "And," she said
coaxingly, and somewhat triumphantly, too, "all my friends have
signed it."
"But," I ejaculated, "I want to
come to some of your meetings before I sign."
"We'll have no more meetings before my report must be sent into
the League," she quietly replied.
But the very feeling of the book
seemed to bring me to my senses.
Straightening my shoulders, but not
lifting my eyes, I began to speak as I
thought big brothers should talk to
their silly little sisters. "Why,",,I

7

began, "don't you know that if
women got votes most of the divorce and property laws now so
favorable to women would be repealed at once? And then one voter,
equal before the law to every other
voter, could not be forced to support any other voter. And don't
you think it is rather piggish for
you to want to have a say about laws
'which men, in all cases, whether
they want to or not, will have to
put into effect just because the
women say so ?"
My courage rose with my satisfaction at having been able to present such plausible arguments under
such trying circumstances. I looked
up, expecting to be able to detect
in her smile or tone of voice her
approval of my attempt to refute
her, even if I must filially retire
under a fire of counter arguments.
But she simply said "No," in her
most dignified tone, and held out
her hand at once for the book. I
had never thought before that one
hand could be more beautiful than
another. "Oh," I stammered, "I
haven't any pencil." But before
she could hand me one, the couples
had arranged themselves for the
next dance, and the music began to
play.
"And thus it Was that Apollo preserved
***
me, too."
Recent Publications.

The January number of the
American Journal of Mathematics
contains an article on "The Double
Tangents of a Binodal Quartic" by
Harry Bateman, who holds the
James Buchanan Johnston Scholarship during the present year.
Professor Terracher writes for
the current (February) number of
Modern Language Notes a brief review of "Vom Ursprung der Provenzalischen Schriftsprache ; von
Heinrich Morf." D. S. Blondheim,
Ph. D. '09, reviews a new history
of French literature by E. Abry, C.
Audic and P. Crouzet, which is
published by Didier, Paris.
"Stratigraphy of the Coal Fields
of Northern New Mexico" is the
title of a dissertation by William T.
Lee of the department of geology,
which has just appeared. The dissertation was submitted in conformity with the requirements for the
degree of doctor of philosophy.
"Some Parallel Formations in
English" by Francis A. Wood, associate professor of Germanic philology in the University of Chicago is the fourth volume to appear of the new series "Hesperia,"
edited by Professor Collitz and Professor Bright.

VOL. XVII, NO. 17.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 17, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

THE ALUMNI BANQUET

MUSICAL CLUBS WIN GLORY

HOPKINS AT THE INAUGURATION

CHAMPION S. A. MILE RELAYERS

To Be Held at the Hotel Belvedere on
February 22 — Year's Officers
to Be Announced.

Large and Interested Audience Turns
Out to Hear the Annual Concert in McCoy Hall.

A Committee Appointed to Arrange the
Details—Position in Parade Dependent on Numbers.

Games at the Armory a Great Success
Hopkins Lowers Record—Eller
Stars for Georgetown.

At the Alumni Banquet, which is
to be held at Hotel Belvedere on
the evening of February 22, the results of the balloting for the coming year's officers of the Alumni
Association of the Johns Hopkins
University will be announced. The
ticket is:

The Musical Clubs gave their annual concert and dance in McCoy
Hall last Tuesday evening. The
weather did not hinder a large and
enthusiastic audience from attending and showing their approval by
calling for repeated encores. Nearly all the seats were taken, and
the clubs feel that they have been
rewarded to some extent for their
labors by the good results from last
Tuesday's concert.
The concert itself was probably
the best the clubs have given in
late years. Favorable comment has
been heard on all sides, and very
little complaint. The Instrumental
Club made an especially good showing, and the instrumental solos held
the attention of everyone. The
quartette and "Mrs. Winslow" won
the laurels for the vocal side of
the concert. The leaders and members of the clubs .are to be congratulated on their good work.
Those who took part in the concert
were: Messrs. Gillet, Fulton, Getz,
Lloyd, Ray, Bacchus, Paulus,
Schmied, Bowden, White, Eiseman,
Spencer, Aler, Scovell, Donoho,
Marston, Howell, Supplee, Spieker,
Randall, Wagner, Breuninger, JacObs, Niles, Weber, Melamet, Niles,
Schneeberger, Uhler, Coblentz,
Lynch, Uhler, Knipp, Tappan, Geissel, Steinmuller, Gminder, Lauchheimer, Cole, Baker, Marshall and
Linthicum.
The ushers were Messrs. Huck,
Dorsey, Rice, Branham, Richardson and Brinton.
The concert was followed by the
usual dance. Last Tuesday's affair
proved to be an especially enjoyable
one. A good orchestra's services
had been secured, and it furnished
excellent music for the new tango
dance. Everyone seemed to enjoy
the dancing thoroughly, and regrets were heard on all sides when
midnight put an end to the pleasure.
Enthusiasts were heard to say that,
for a long time McCoy Hall had
never been the scene of a dance
where the attendance was as large,
the dancers as enthusiastic, the women as beautifully gowned and the
music as good as last Tuesday.
• On Saturday, February 22, the
clubs will give a concert and dance
in Salisbury. On the twenty-fifth
they will perform at one of the Baltimore churches, and will go to
Catonsville on the twenty-seventh.
Two or three other concerts are being planned to follow these, but no
dates have as yet been definitely
arranged.

With the assurance of a representative portion of the student
body at a mass-meeting last week
that Johns Hopkins would have a
large number of marchers in the inaugural parade in Washington on
March 4, Chairman Freddie Lee
appointed the following committee
to arrange details for the University's delegation: Walter D. Sutton
(chairman), John Sharp Dickinson, C. Leland Getz, President J.
Miller Leake of the Hopkins Wilson Club, John C. Branham, Steuart D. White, Blanchard Randall,
Arthur Primrose and Lewis Breuninger. Freddie Lee will also serve.
The committee, while composed
of undergraduates with but two exceptions, will make an effort to enlist alumni, medical, graduate and
undergraduate students.
In view of the fact that a suspension of exercises has been
granted by the faculty and the
proximity of Washington, the University should turn out the second
largest delegation in the college
men's division of the parade.
Princeton, of course, will lead in
numbers. Already over 1,200 have
decided to march for their former
president, and they will be first
in line.
Johns Hopkins; University of
Virginia and Davidson College will
follow Princeton according to the
size of the delegation.
A letter received from the committee of arrangements for the
parade said in part:
"Therefore, it is apparent that
the position of your delegation will
depend on the result of your efforts
to enlist men."
The question of what is to be
worn by the marchers has not yet
been decided upon, but it is hoped
that caps and gowns will be selected. Across the gowns a band bearing "Johns Hopkins" will be worn.
All marchers must be dressed in
a uniform style. If it is decided not
to wear caps and gowns, some other
style of dress will be selected.
Hopkins wants second place in
the line, and it will not be to the
credit of the students to fall 'behind any other institution than
Princeton. The demonstration is
non-partisan, without political significance, and will be purely patriotic in chatacter. The faculty has
allowed a holiday, and it is with the
condition that the student body
should go to a man. It may seldom
occur that the University will have a

Johns Hopkins, in the most thrilling of the relay races at the Fifth
Regiment - Johns Hopkins games
last Saturday night at the Armory,
lowered the only South Atlantic
Association record broken during
the meet.
The event, too, makes the Black
4nd Blue team the champion South
Atlantic mile relayers. The time
was 3 minutes 3375 seconds as
against 3 minutes and 37 seconds
registered by the McCulloh Athletic
Club some time ago.
Captain Catlin, Lloyd, Wells and
McDonagh of the Hopkins team
had saved up their strength at the
sacrifice of other events and throwing all energy into the race they
were. determined to nose the victory
from Washington and Lee and the
University of Virginia.
Perhaps the prettiest run of the
four was made by Lloyd, the third
man, who made up a dangerous
lead, giving Catlin one yard to his
advantage at the start of the last
lap. Catlin was pushed for the position, but broke the tape only a few
inches ahead of Cooke, Virginia's
star relay man.
The race was the most interesting and thrilling of the meet, and
a suprisingly large gallery of Hopkins rooters made a convention-like
din of cheers and hullabaloos when
Catlin was carried from the finish
by Hopkins men.
Another relay won by Hopkins—
that for the State mile championship
—called forth cheering. St. John's
College withdrew from the event,
leaving Western Maryland to contest Hopkins. Wagner, Ray, Stiehel and Groover composed the team.
Bob Eller of Georgetown was the
shining star of the games. He
carried off four firsts, three of
which were South Atlantic championships. The other championship
was won by Gallagher, also of
Georgrtown. The events were the
S. A. A. A. U. 100-yard dash,
ioo-yard hurdles, 220-yard dash
and the open 100-yard hurdles, all
won by Eller; and the 88o-yard run
won by Gallagher.
In the 100-yard dash for the
South Atlantic championship Wagner of Hopkins was second to Eller,
but the men were so close that to
those who stood near the finish it
looked as if the Hopkins man had
won. White and Voshell placed in the heats.
In the field events other Hopkins
men took places. Blanco, the Porto

Together with this ballot there
was sent out to all graduates of the
University a ballot for members of
the Alumni Council. The Alumni
Council is the alumni body which
confers with the University authorities on matters of common interest.
They are, also, the organizers of
movements in which it is desirable
that all the alumni should take part.
Those chosen for the honor serve
four years, but all members do not
vacate office the same year. At
least one of the successful candidates must be a new member of the
Council.

THE MADISON

Y. W. C. A. Conference.

A conference for volunteer and
employed workers of the Young
Women's Christian Association was
opened in McCoy Hall last Monday, February io, at 8.15 P. M.
The meeting was presided over by
Joshua Levering and was addressed
by Dr. Walter Rauschenbusch of
the Rochester Theological Seminary on the subject of "Christian
Social Service." Dr. Rauschenbusch is an authority on this subject, having written numerous books
and delivered a series of lectures
before the leading universities of
this country. He was one of the
leaders in the recent convention of
the Federal Council of Churches of
Christ in America, and has done
much work in mapping out the
program of community service,
which many churches have adopted.
Besides this meeting, there were
two other sessions of the conference, both of which were held in
the Y. W. C. A. Building, Park
avenue and Monument street. On
Tuesday there was a session from
II to 1.30, which was continued
at 3.45 P. M. The last session was
held on Wednesday, at 10.30 A. M.
and 8.15 P. M. The meetings were
addressed by Baltimore pastors, and
by the chairmen of different councils and committees.

From Far-Away India.

An interesting communication recently received by THE NEWSLETTER is a report of the A. E. L.
Mission College, Guntur, India,
which was sent by L. L. Uhl, Ph.
D., president of the college, who has
spent his life spreading Western
learning in this far-off quarter of
the globe. From the report one
gets a picture of a college so
strangely unlike any college with
which we are familiar, that it
seems to be from another world
or another age.
In the first place, the enrollment
is made up of 712 Hindus, 195
Christians and 61 Mohammedans,
together with a smaller number of
Visva Brahmans, Vaisyas, Naidis,
Reddis, Salis, Bhogams, and so on.
At the April examinations only
72Y2 per cent, of the pupils passed
the examinations and were promoted, which shows the extreme difficulty which missionaries have to
enable Hindus to master Western
culture. Irregular attendance is
complained of not only in regard to
the pupils but also in regard to the
masters, who often stay away on
account of Hindu ceremonies, indisposition and frequent summonses
for jury duty. At the meetings of
the literary society, we are told, the
students fill even the doors and
aisles to hear the debates, showing
the eagerness of the students to
learn.

THE NEWS - LETTER publishes

It is recorded of the famous
Adams Sherman Hill (author of the
late lamented text-book of Rhetoric

on everything from the way the
government was being run to the
manner in which his fried eggs
were served for breakfast; and that
being asked to explain this attitude
he declared that the world would
be very bad off if everybody was
a kicker, but that a small leaven of
that disagreeable species was absolutely necessary to make the world
go 'round. THE NEWS-LETTER
agrees with Professor Hill in the
belief that a cheerful knocker is an
indispensable member of society
and a person who is deeply interested in the welfare of the University having recently evinced himself ready to undertake the duties

Prof. Buchanan Lectures.

Prof. Milton A. Buchanan of the
University of Toronto delivered a
series of three lectures last week in
the Romance Seminary on the famous Spanish satirist and journalist,
Mariano Jose de Larra. On Wednesday the visitor's subject was
"The Life and Writings of Larra";
on Thursday he spoke on "Larra's
Views on Contemporary Romanticism," and on Friday he discussed
"Larra's Attitude Toward Political
and Social Conditions." Professor
Buchanan is one of a number of
men who will be brought here this
year to deliver lectures before the
Romance department.

Professor Ames' Lectures.

Prof. Ames' course of lectures, at
Northwestern University, will begin on Monday evening, February
24. The course is called "The Norman W. Harris Lectures" and is
given annually upon the same general plan as our Turnbull lectures.
The subject of the course is "The
Constitution of Matter," and six
lectures will be delivered, one each
day of the week of February 24.
On his way out to Evanston, Dr.
Ames will meet the John Hopkins
Alumni at a dinner in Cleveland.
After the course at Northwestern
University is completed he will go
to Chicago, where a luncheon will
be held in his honor by the Northwestern Alumni Association of the
Johns Hopkins University. On
March 4 Dr. Ames will deliver two
lectures at Madison, Wis.—one to
the University of Wisconsin and
one to the members Of the faculty
in physics.

Attack and Defense Both Showing Up

Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

•

Item in the Public Press:

"HOPKINS TO MARCH IN PARADE
Students in Cap and Gown to Join
Inaugural Procession."

Of course there's no need for
more publicity at Hopkins. Why
spend good money when we are
getting free space such as this?
Just think how much it adds to the
dignity of the University. Our
numbers will be doubled next year.
Would the Third Ward Democrats
and Concord Clubbers send their
sons anywhere else after hobnobbing with our learned professors as
they two-step down Pennsylvania
avenue? Of course not:'twould be
absurd to think of anything else.

MORE PUBLICITY.
"President Wilson Invited to Referee
Armory Meet."

Of course he will come—it will
add so much to his dignity.

Lacrosse prospects are brightening with each practice. Last Saturday the attack showed evidences of
real team work, driving in goal
after goal, and the coaches were
very well pleased. At the next
regular practice the defense began
to show signs of the drilling of the
past two months. This is particularly evident in one or two cases.
Price, for one, is showing marked
improvement and, if he continues the
good work, it looks as though he
may hold down a place on the team.
Beatty, too, is looming up as a
possibility; his stick-work can still
be improved, but it is getting more
certain with each practice and he
is working hard for a position.
The trouble, at present, is that
a number of men are shirking. La
Motte, for example, has not yet
been out, and several others are
cutting practice entirely too often.
Besides hurting the team, these men
are seriously risking their own
chances, for the squad is large;
several good men are trying for
each position, and it is the men
who are out at every practice who
will land the jobs.

February 13, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

I have come to the conclusion that
cartoonists are all wrong in making
woman suffragists hideous beings.
At least, the one with whom I sat
out a dance last Tuesday evening
certainly had beautiful eyes, to my
way of thinking at any rate. "Oh,
there goes Grace," she began, as we
took our seats out in the hall: "I
haven't seen her since Mrs. Pratt
gave that tea to the new members
of the Equal Suffrage League. I
suppose you have signed the petition."
The cynical smile which came
over my face as I said, "What petition?" suffered an untimely eclipse
when my eyes met the two blue eyes
of my companion, which now had
a strangely unfamiliar look. But
_perhaps it was only the shadow of
some dancer that fell upon us for
a moment that made me fear that
the eyes of my companion were indeed like summer skies (to which
I had secretly compared them),
which so easily become overcast
with clouds, the prophets of a *coming storm.
"No, as I have never had the
pleasure of meeting any real suffragettes, I have never signed the petition. Are they really so very ugly ?"
I said in vain hope of changing the
topic of the conversation.
"Oh," she said, "I have a book
here which you can sign without
having to meet the awful suffragettes," and she pulled out from
nowhere a beautiful, gilt edge memorandum book. "And," she said
coaxingly, and somewhat triumphantly, too, "all my friends have
signed it."
"But," I ejaculated, "I want to
come to some of your meetings before I sign."
"We'll have no more meetings before my report must be sent into
the League," she quietly replied.
But the very feeling of the book
seemed to bring me to my senses.
Straightening my shoulders, but not
lifting my eyes, I began to speak as I
thought big brothers should talk to
their silly little sisters. "Why,",,I

7

began, "don't you know that if
women got votes most of the divorce and property laws now so
favorable to women would be repealed at once? And then one voter,
equal before the law to every other
voter, could not be forced to support any other voter. And don't
you think it is rather piggish for
you to want to have a say about laws
'which men, in all cases, whether
they want to or not, will have to
put into effect just because the
women say so ?"
My courage rose with my satisfaction at having been able to present such plausible arguments under
such trying circumstances. I looked
up, expecting to be able to detect
in her smile or tone of voice her
approval of my attempt to refute
her, even if I must filially retire
under a fire of counter arguments.
But she simply said "No," in her
most dignified tone, and held out
her hand at once for the book. I
had never thought before that one
hand could be more beautiful than
another. "Oh," I stammered, "I
haven't any pencil." But before
she could hand me one, the couples
had arranged themselves for the
next dance, and the music began to
play.
"And thus it Was that Apollo preserved
***
me, too."
Recent Publications.

The January number of the
American Journal of Mathematics
contains an article on "The Double
Tangents of a Binodal Quartic" by
Harry Bateman, who holds the
James Buchanan Johnston Scholarship during the present year.
Professor Terracher writes for
the current (February) number of
Modern Language Notes a brief review of "Vom Ursprung der Provenzalischen Schriftsprache ; von
Heinrich Morf." D. S. Blondheim,
Ph. D. '09, reviews a new history
of French literature by E. Abry, C.
Audic and P. Crouzet, which is
published by Didier, Paris.
"Stratigraphy of the Coal Fields
of Northern New Mexico" is the
title of a dissertation by William T.
Lee of the department of geology,
which has just appeared. The dissertation was submitted in conformity with the requirements for the
degree of doctor of philosophy.
"Some Parallel Formations in
English" by Francis A. Wood, associate professor of Germanic philology in the University of Chicago is the fourth volume to appear of the new series "Hesperia,"
edited by Professor Collitz and Professor Bright.
